header.relationships: Close family, partners, very close friends
header.topics: Food, trampolining, feeling sick, colours, family, getting older and needing help, triangles, cost of nursing home care, looking after parents, singing, pronouncing foreign names, autistic spectrum.
header.activity: Table conversation with ANON and ANON

speaker.occupation: not currently working, caring for toddler

yeah I've been worried about housework and

somebody got me a cleaner and did the housework

because it's got worse you know? previously she could cope quite well with the Alzheimer's do you want another slice of pizza darling? help yourself then erm because my dad just sleeps most of the time it's part of the epilepsy and the epilepsy medication he just sleeps all the time he's quite capable of sleeping all through the day all through the evening getting up for some food

he's a man with Alzheimer's and epilepsy you know?
oh it's your dad has the Alzheimer's?

does it? has he always had epilepsy?
he was diagnosed about four or five years ago

mm I don't know actually I don't know I've always treated it as a separate thing but it does go through phases of erm but my mum has said now she is struggling to cope so I need to I need to have and that's a big thing for my mum to say that you know? cos normally she's like yeah it's fine cos she leads a pretty good life really
you know? she's out and about all the time cos he's asleep in the day

she just gets herself home for the evening you know where she gets him up and in fact now I think it's starting to change cos she's having to do loads of laundry and it's just depressing that kind of thing you know?
yeah does she have anyone come in like a nurse?
yeah that's taken a lot of persuading but it it's on an ad hoc basis cos she can't predict
and she obviously has her own health things
erm which again is sporadic you know?
so sometimes it's sometimes she's more needy than other times you know?

that's that's the top end of things and the kind of not-so-great care home is between seven hundred and fifty and eight hundred you will not get cheaper

because because my mum lived in the house they can't touch the house cos that's her home and she has a cancer diagnosis as well so they double can't touch her so when their savings are exhausted
then the state will step in to a degree
but you're expected to contribute still some of that
how? how much of a degree?
I don't know but it's means-tested
so why doesn't she just give all her money to you?
I have no no no no you're right she has given me seeing as we're talking quite frankly about these things she has given me fifty grand and I think she's given my brother fifty grand
so like she'll have no moves like as a mechanism or just here's before I waste it all?
she gave it to me be for with the intention of it being for a deposit cos I don't own a property but it because I don't own property so she gave it to me as a
it was more I'll give it to my two children before I lose it all
but you have to do that by law within seven years it's the seven year rule so if they see that you've done that within that seven years that's still counts against you
it's a bit like abating your creditors in bankruptcy or something
that was over seven years ago was it?

no it was only in in January she gave it to me so it's very very punitive we do need to have another proper conversation about it because I think the reality is that because there's a lot of equity in the house
you know it's a house in you know? it's a lot of money there
so we need to really properl my mum hates this stuff and I don't really like this stuff either

and they own it outright there's no mortgage or anything like that so we do have to look very carefully at this huge asset really and what we do with it

you know? so he can't do a lot from really

plan a bit do you know what I mean? as and weigh up the possibilities
